stem: While riding the subway you notice a stranger quickly glancing at your phone as you type your PIN. They appear to angle their own camera toward your screen.

choices.A: Turn slightly, shield the screen, and continue typing
choices.B: If possible, wait to unlock until you reach a private spot
choices.C: Let them watch; the PIN is short anyway
choices.D: Say your PIN out loud to confuse them

stem: A pop-up on your tablet says: “Boost battery life, grant device-admin rights to our optimizer.”

choices.A: Deny and look for optimization tips from the maker
choices.C: Test it by granting access then revoke the access afterwards to be safe

stem: A rideshare driver offers to plug your phone into their dashboard USB for faster charging.

choices.A: Plug in quickly as battery is low
choices.C: Use your own portable power bank instead
choices.B: Plug in but turn phone off first to be safe
choices.D: Hand the driver your own cable to use

stem: A free weather widget asks for permission to access your phone’s accessibility settings to update temperature even on the lock screen.

choices.A: Grant access, lock-screen data is helpful
choices.D: Deny and search for a simpler widget that needs fewer permissions

stem: An email from a phone-repair shop claims your device qualifies for a free remote tune-up. They request you install a screen-sharing app and input a one-time code so they can verify device health.

choices.A: Install and share screen to get tune-up
choices.C: Decline and visit a trusted repair center in person if needed
choices.D: Share code while monitoring their actions

stem: You must share your phone temporarily with a sibling to let them use a navigation app. In 1–3 sentences, describe how you would protect your private apps and data during that time.

rubric.point: Enable guest mode or app lock/folder lock
Log out or hide sensitive apps (banking, email)
Supervise usage or set time limit, then review device afterward
